Problem:
Consider a system governed by the partial differential equation \\(\\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = Pu\\), where \\(P\\) is a differential operator. Investigate how the introduction of a boundary condition using the function \\(h(u) = e^{Qt}u\\) at time \\(t = 0\\), where \\(Q\\) is another differential operator, affects the system.

If \\(h(u)\\) is applied to the initial function \\(u_0\\) and then the system evolves under \\(\\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = Pu\\) without further intervention, will the state \\(u(t)\\) at time \\(t = T\\) be equivalent to the state if \\(u_0\\) were evolved directly under \\(\\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = Pu\\)?
Explanation: Applying the \\(h(u)\\) boundary condition modifies the initial state by redefining \\(u(0)\\) as \\(e^{Qt}u_0\\). Since \\(e^{Qt}\\) affects the initial condition, the evolution of \\(u(t)\\) under \\(P\\) will follow a different path compared to starting from \\(u_0\\) without modification.
